Sparkfun sells an OBD2 connector ( http://www.sparkfun.com/products/9911 ) that is very useful for those wanting to connect their car to their mighty Arduino. (They also sell OBD2 to DB9 cables, but where's the fun in that?) ;-) But once you've finished soldering, you'll want to protect those shiny bits from dust and smoke. That's what this cover is for.

Print both cover halves. Join them around the connector (rectangular hole) and cable (round hole). Glue them or secure them using rubber bands, cable ties, nylon thread... You may need to sand them to ensure a proper fit.

It is common in cooking for recipes to call for a Pinch of salt, sugar, or spice. A pinch is 1/16 of a teaspoon, if you do not have a pinch measuring spoon handy most people would just guess. Over salting or spicing a meal is an easy thing to do, but not with the Just a Pinch Shaker, you get a pinch every time! There it nothing else like it on the market! When the Just a Pinch Shaker is tilted upside down only one "Pinch" comes out each time. It must be tilted back to refill the cavity for another pinch on the next tilt. This is my first design. I created it using Tinkercad for the #CountertopChallenge. Within 24 Hours of learning Tinkercad I generated and printed my first working prototype. Printed with ABS, 10% fill, 0.3 layer height. Supports are already added for successful printing
**Additional supports are not needed.

title: Raspberry Pi B+ Holder for Da Vinci Octoprint +++ Now with lids+++
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi, made a housing for my Raspberry running octoprint.
Keeps everything nice and tidy. It fit's perfect and the carriage has about 1mm clearance. You can run the cables through the inside of the printer (see pictures)
Cut or drill holes for your cables afterwards in the walls. Easier than printing with support or bridging. Be careful with your slicer. One of the long walls was somehow sliced hollow. Now with 3 lids! One with the classic Unreal Tournament logo, one with the Octoprint logo and one empty, so you can stance your own logo in. Have fun with customizing and post some makes! Forgot to mention, this is for the Raspberry Pi B +. If you want, I can edit the file for the other versions.

Barely fits the bed. Printed at 0.3 layer hight completely solid.
Don't be canny wiht brim. I printed with 5mm. Printed the lid with brim to and actually didn't remove the brim. It makes a nice sealing lip. Printed in blue glow in the dark ABS (Couldn't resist this stuff)

author: straxus07

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/l5qXwnYfJuA

I was messing around with an Arduino prototype, but my water-clear LEDs were being both difficult to video and blinding to look at.  I was using anything for a diffuser - paper, polythene bags, etc.  (I had no pingpong balls or white straws - the usual suspects).
So, enter the printable, 5mm LED diffuser.
It's not pretty, but it's incredibly sturdy!

There are two files here, depending on how you wish to use this. Shrink-Fit Diffuser
If you have the LED to hand when you're printing, you can use the 'shrink' model. As soon as the printer has finished depositing ABS, squeekily pop the LED into the diffuser before it cools. It will shrink to a very tight, near-permanent fit. Press-Fit (Non-Shrink) Diffuser
If you want to print these for later use, go for the 10% scaled up 'noshrink' version. This will be a tight fit when cooled, but will go in with a bit of care and maybe some pliers. No raft required. (Please note, the photograph was taken of the LEDs when they are fading up and down. The exact brightness of them is pretty random at any one moment.) Video of the LEDs fading (not using printed diffusers):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=syGVw7-35r0
Blog post about the LEDs fading, including the Arduino code:
http://myriadwhimsies.wordpress.com/2011/03/20/i-love-you-like-nature-loves-sine-waves/

comments.text: Thats a smart and simple idea! Does anyone know the shrinking ratio of ABS? Should one compensate for this when printing with strict measurement specs in mind?
comments.author: scocioba

title: Printable water cooling jacket for v6 type hotends.

description.text:
As the name says, this is a printable jacket to convert v6 type hotends to water cooled. It seals to the aluminium heatsink with two O rings so the position of the outlet water pipes can be adjusted (this also helps with dismantling).
The printed material of the jacket hides behind the last cooling fin of the heatsink to protect it from the heat block and is water cooled (more insulation between the heat block may be needed).
The principal is that if it can keep the filament down its centre cool enough to print then it can keep its self cool enough to survive.
The intended use is for enclosed extruders that have a high internal ambient temperature or use high temperature filaments. If you have a 50 degree ambient inside your enclosure then you have to use 50 degree air to cool your heatsink. The water in theory could be just above freezing or maintained at a constant of your choice. Or as has been pointed out multi head setups where it reduces the need for lots of fans.
Designed to be easy to print even with basic setup, filp the .stl 180 deg (X or Y axis) to print. To avoid leaks everything has to have tight tolerances. It is likley that you will have to do some clean up work on this print. Edits / Changes:
  • New .stl file for jacket as wrong one uploaded.
  • Photo & .stl for retaining clips added.
  • A tool .stl added to help clean up the inside of the jacket if required.
    • Notes:
  • v6_jacket_V2_f.stl was 1.25 mm short in its overall length (my bad uploaded the wrong file) only 3 people downloaded this, sorry.
    v6_jacket_V3_f.stl is correct.
  • Larger bracket is for k8200, will post .stl when confirmed it works as expected.
  • Print tool, fit an m5 bolt through hole in the end & secure with a nut. Insert sand paper into slot an sand away.

There is a .dxf file in the downloads that may answer some questions.
How it works:
The printed jacket slides onto the modified heatsink from the top (filament inlet end) and uses two O rings to seal onto it (20 & 18 mm). When assembled the jacket needs to be pushed downwards 0.25 mm to compress the O rings, this will be achieved in different ways depending on your application and mounting method. The simplest is a 1.5 mm thick ‘U’ shaped lock that slides into the gap between the little 16 mm fin and the mounting area. In my case (k8200) the mounting bracket will maintain the pressure (I’ll post a photo). The jacket is the same size as the last fin and hides behind it to stop it melting, that combined with the fact that both the jacket and the fin are cooled by the water should ensure it survival.
What to do and what you need:
The jacket has two 5 mm holes for water inlet and outlet. Decide, what size pipe you are going to use. Then how you are going to attach it to the jacket. I used plastic 3/8 pipe couplers cut in half and glued into the 5 mm holes. If your printing is good enough you may wish to print spigots. Modify the file and print. Mine used 600mm of 3mm and took about 2 mins (2.5mm layres, 4 perimeters to make most of it solid).
You need two O rings, 20 x 1.5mm & 18 x 1.5 mm (softer the better, the red ones are really good). They must be 1.5mm, anything bigger will not work with these files.
Now the heat sink. It has 12 fins, 1 is 16 mm dia we don’t do anything to this. The other 11 are 22mm, the middle 9 need to be removed and the top one needs to be reduced in size to 18 mm dia. The method is up to you, I used a bench grinder to remove most of the material then finished with a small file. IMPORTANT: don’t damage the top of the heat block end fin, the O ring has to seal on this. Use tape or even print a little guard to protect it. Once removed the top fin needs to be reduced to 18 mm. I scribed a line to work to, then ground most of the material off and finished with a file. Top tip: This fin needs to be 1 mm per side bigger than the rest of the bits at that end, I found a knife blade that was 1mm thick and used it to both protect the other parts but to ensure that the fin was 1 mm bigger and concentric.
Now you have all the parts: fit the O rings onto the heatsink, then slide the jacket into place ensuring the O rings are correctly seated. Compress the O rings and fit the locking device (more details on that to follow).
Connect up the water etc.
I recommend that you run a test to ensure that this will work in your environment before printing.
Warning: This item is made available for use by people modifying their printers. As every printer is different it is up to you to assess the risks involved in your application. In all, at sometime it will contain hot water which can burn and dammage electrical items. Please becarefull. Thanks to this guy for ideas: http://forum.e3d-online.com/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=66

comments.author: medic265

comments.text:
This is really great. I started to design my own then found yours!
I would make one suggestion - move the water connections to the bottom of the sleeve nearer the heater block, as this is where cooling is needed the most. Or move just the inlet down there, keeping the outlet at the top.
Obviously the thermal conductivity of water and aluminium are pretty great anyway, but this might just add a little bit more performance, ensuring less heat difference between top/bottom :).
What tubing are you using?
comments.author: AS_Motion_Lab

comments.text: Hi, thanks for the comments. I started with the idea of having the inlet at the bottom but didn’t like it as it meant the water pipe was nearer to the heater. I then swapped to having the inlet in its current position but printed the body as an Oo type shape where the smaller ’o’ carried the water to the bottom of the body. After printing a prototype I decided that as the body was only 27mm long and water had the potential to offer much better cooling, so I was over engineering and you have the current design.  As for the plastic tube, I had some leftover from a pond aerator pump.
comments.author: AS_Motion_Lab

comments.text: Good idea. I believe that water cooling is going to become much more popular once more people realize the advantages of enclosing and heating their build chambers - especially for ABS printing. In many cases, cooling for steppers is also going to become mandatory, and that can easily be accomplished with cheap CPU cooling blocks. I am working on a project to water cool my XYZ DaVinci v1.0, and have a generic radiator and water pump mounting bracket that you might find useful here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:723309
comments.author: KDan

comments.text:
Hi KDan, thanks, I agree with cooling & the pump mount looks good. I haven’t started work on the reservoirs yet (that’s next week’s job).
My thoughts are that there will two, one smaller & higher than the hotend the other larger & lower than the hotend where the pump will be located.
The water will be pumped from the lower one through the jacket & into the higher one. Once the higher one is full it will overflow back through a separate pipe to the lower.
This might seem a bit over the top, but I was concerned about what would happen in the event of a power fail to the printer effectively shutting down the cooling whilst the heater block was still hot. With this system the top reservoir would slowly drain back through the hotend jacket & pump to the lower, preventing the jacket getting hot enough to be damaged or the water in the jacket boiling. This also means that when powered off, most of the water is drained to the lowest part of the system (only a small quantity is left in the jacket), which will help with maintainance.
comments.author: KDan

comments.text:
Not sure why you'd need two reservoirs. The pump and radiator system I'm using is a pretty standard setup for water cooling computer CPU's. The pump and integrated reservoir is mounted at the highest point so that fluid can be added to completely fill the system and purge all the air. In the event of a power failure, I doubt there is enough thermal energy stored in the heater block to cause any issues whatsoever. I think most of it will be lost to direct radiation rather than conduction up through the heat break. I understand your concern though - you don't want the water in there to boil. I just have my doubts that it would happen.
Best way to check would be to simulate a power failure and leave the reservoir uncapped in the unlikely event that localized boiling did occur.

comments.text: It is an ingenious design that would most likely work if it weren't for the ears on the door being too far apart.  The door fit is rather sloppy and binds/falls off in use.  Move the ears of the trap door closer together when you make the redesign.  Also, PB is rather messy.  I use sunflower seed and it always gets the mouse.  It is also much easier to clean the trap.  However, in this trap the bait is uphill and sunflower seeds slide down hill rather easily.  Put a raised section across the floor to hold the seeds or other bate.  Make it the full width, about 3/16" high, and about 3/4" from the end.  These additions might unbalance the trap so you might want to add a little length to the open end of the trap to counter the extra weight.  Also, PB and crackers might be adding enough weight to cause the trap trip by itself with some minor vibration such as a door closing or someone walking across the floor near the trap.  All in all a nice job.

description.text: A simple shot glass.  Seven sided and twisted using a helix tool in the CAD software.  Mounted on a flared to base to reduce the chance of tipping.  The interior has been rounded to ease cleaning.  Should hold very close to an ounce of liquid.  These are the first part of a slightly larger project.

For 3D printing, a solid infill is recommended to reduce the chance of leaking.  The original set saw some outdoor winter use and the guess is that some shrinkage resulted in a slight leak in some of the glasses.  A later printing with an infill of 1.0 hasn't had this problem.

description.text: You may know that it is possible to color regions on a map using 4 colors so that no two touching regions share the same color. Print two copies of each DoublePart and one copy of the SinglePart (using 7 different colors of filament, of course) and the pegs.  I used supports to print, and I actually only use six of the pegs because it's too hard to get everything to line up with all seven.  (I hope to fix this later).

title: The best tools for 3D print removal

description.text: I found that I have the best luck on my Replicator2 of printing directly on the acrylic bed, but removal of prints with alot of surface area against the bed can be a pain.  After much trial and error, I have come across the best one-two punch for removing prints from your print bed.  The tool on the left is a simple paint scraper which holds old-school razor blades and is usually used to scrape paint off of windows.  The tool on the right is actually sold at Wal-Mart as a food chopper and is essentially a flat piece of stainless steel rolled on one end for a handle and with a beveled blade on the other.  I slide the razor blade carefully around all edges to start the print loosening and then use the chopper under the loosened edge to pop off the print.  Works perfect and haven't ruined or failed on a single print!  Enjoy!

comments.text: try the lil chizzler. http://www.amazon.com/Lil-Chizler-Vinyl-Label-Scraping/dp/B00AZKR2CY/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1426693250&sr=8-1&keywords=lil+chizzler. I just started using it and found it awesome. It usually gets the print off without removing the tape.

title: gopro holder for Kodak Sport - also for Iris+ quadcopter camera Mount

description.text: Who needs a gopro?  This simple device can be used to snuggly and safely hold an EIS Kodak Play Sport camera for easy mounting to a drone or gopro mount on another device. I desinged it to use the gopro mount and attach to my IRIS+ Drone.

I printed with 3 shells, and 30% fill, but you can cut some weight with as little as 10% fill and still have good strength.   The gopro mount is a remix of Streamlined Contour to GoPro Mount Adapters from WheresWaldo I just removed the slots on the attachment side, so that you can just glue the mount on to the flat surface on the back side.  In my case, I like to use PVC cement (the kind you use on PVC pipe joining), cause it is fast, and has a nice cotton ball to apply a dab.   You can also use thing:649261 (Action Cam Mount).  
Just to be super safe, I added some velcro pads to each arm, and a simple velcro cord wrap to snugly secure across the font.  There is no way that camera is coming out of this holder.

author: gianfranco

description.text:
I wanted to go ahead and develop Hololens apps. Here is Microsoft's live demo video: https://youtu.be/qym11JnFQBM After experimenting and seeing a couple AR kickstarters, I figured out a way to develop comparable hardware... at least for prototyping. https://youtu.be/omNDLQ4cKnY The HMD costs ~$10 and it projects any mobile phone image enlarged at 16" from the eye. I plan to add a Leap Motion, depth sensor, and/or tracking to be able to interact with virtual objects. Please share! https://twitter.com/seanfultonhall Edit: TBD items:
Google Tango tablet integration:
All inclusive sensors and mobile form-factor (fastest road to victory):
https://www.google.com/atap/project-tango/
Without Google Tango:
Depth sensor could also just be a head mounted Kinect using: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5601
Head tracking could be done with Playstation Move.me at first: http://code.google.com/p/moveme/
Added ideas not on the real Hololens:
Pupil tracking idea here: http://sourceforge.net/projects/haytham/?source=navbar or http://code.google.com/p/pupil/

Update 2015-09-07: Added the two files I used as the base.  If you leave off the additional reflector piece, you can experiment with moving the display and lens and even adding more fresnel lenses (easily obtained at Office Depot and online).  I had trouble combining them into one mesh.  I apologize for it taking so long.  I figured this would be at least better for those who have big enough printers to spit this thing out in one shot.  I'll keep working on the one-piece version.

Update 2015-12-09: I haven't been able to try the real Hololens yet, but from what I can gather, the real Hololens has narrower FOV and does not use pupil tracking for gaze tracking as I have suggested here. From what I have heard, you must point your entire head at things and the FOV is super tiny... can anyone tell me if this is true? I hope to demo it soon, but have been having a lot of near misses when it comes to opportunities to try it for myself. Also I have not been able to determine at what distance the Hololens projects images and whether it is dynamic. Any information would be greatly appreciated and will inspire me to get this thing finished. I appreciate any patience up until this point, as I am transitioning work wise and haven't been able to pursue the software side of things whole-heartedly yet.
The Google Tango tablet is a great platform on which all the sensors and processing necessary for the Hololens experience are present. It currently cost $512 compared to the $3000 pricetag on the Hololens. It will probably require separating the screen from the sensors on the back of the tablet, but if anyone has one and is interested, they are but a few steps away from completing the DIY Hololens experience.

Cut a piece of 2.5mm thick plexi-glass or other reflective-transparent material to 95mm x 127mm (or longer). Something akin to this http://www.homedepot.com/p/LEXAN-11-in-x-14-in-x-0-093-in-Clear-Polycarbonate-Sheet-GE-34/205437907?N=5yc1vZbrdg You may have to file the slot that holds it, but otherwise it should slide into place nicely. I actually left the protective film on one side to help with reflection, even at the cost of blurring the real world a little. If you remove it from both sides, there will be a sharp "ghost," or slightly offset double image. I will try some one-way film soon. Currently I have this mirror mounted inside: http://www.amazon.com/dp/B008MB1AZ8/ref=pe_385040_127541860_TE_3p_dp_1 but I'm thinking I need more curvature, so I may replace with bike rear-view or something similiar. Simply mount centered, convex side up, on the inside of the 45 degree angled part on top. And one of these magnifiers is inside as well: http://www.officedepot.com/a/products/787235/Carson-MagniMark-Magnifier/ Cut length down to 153mm (cut off the end with the tie on it) and place over the opening that is created on top before gluing on the two final "additional-reflector" parts. Otherwise, just print and stick (hot glue) the pieces together. I used support material and simply had to rotate some of the pieces to a more suitable orientation for supports. Oh and weather stripping for the face padding! Pending: an actual mount for the phone. I made it for Note3/4, and currently you need to use gaffer's tape or your fingers to hold the phone in place during use. Also pending is a Leap Motion or depth sensor mount for virtual object manipulation. I may even add a Raspberry Pi and camera for gaze detection. Edit: TBD items:
Google Tango tablet integration:
All inclusive sensors and mobile form-factor (fastest road to victory):
https://www.google.com/atap/project-tango/
Without Google Tango:
Depth sensor could also just be a head mounted Kinect using: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5601
Head tracking could be done with Playstation Move.me at first: http://code.google.com/p/moveme/
Added ideas not on the real Hololens:
Pupil tracking idea here: http://sourceforge.net/projects/haytham/?source=navbar or http://code.google.com/p/pupil/

author: jerda86

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/09ov3sFlIqJ
Original  Red and White Pokeball

This is a Mute Cornett designed by Steven Silverstein: http://silversteinligature.com/ I did nothing but take his measurements and put them into stl files. The Cornett needed to be cut into four pieces to fit into my print area. To facilitate gluing the pieces together I created alignment cones meant to keep the pieces aligned in the X-Y plane during the glue up. These truncated cones are the negative space at the center of the Cornett. I glued each piece together with two part epoxy. To keep the internal alignment cones from getting glued as well I wrapped the alignment cones in silicone embedded parchment paper. Both the alignment cones and the pieces of parchment paper came out with no fuss.

Print Warning!  I went beyond the normal print limits on my Rep2 to cut down the number of sections from five to four.  I edited the gcode to prevent the nozzle from clipping the top of the sections in the end code section.  For example one of the parts is 157mm tall.  The nominal end gcode calls for the z-axis to be moved to 155mm.  I edited the code to move the z-axis to 158.   
I have tried printing these both solid and with three shells and 15% infill.  At .34, .15 and .10  My main goal is to get these pieces air tight. They were not entirely airtight so I coated the whole Cornett inside and out with a coat clear Shellac. When the Cornett is assembled the lowest note played should be A440.  
I printed the alignment codes at 99.5% scale, 2 shells 5 percent infill, and .34 layer thickness.

title: Fully Customize-able Combination Recipe Stand/Ingredient Holder

description.text: It is an all around cooking area. On top there's and adjustable book stand. In it fit 5 drawers, that hold Flour, Salt, Sugar, Baking Soda, and Baking Powder. On each side are a set of holes to insert extensions, making it fully customize-able. Just put any number of the Add-On's you want on either side. There are currently 4 types of Add-On's I've designed, Spice Rack, Extra Drawer, Large Utensil Slot(Fits some measuring cups), and Small Utensil Slot. The Rendered Image below shows it with all of the Add-On's I designed. The pegs are compatible with each other, and you can make your own Add-On's to fit your needs. Fits most places on counter tops.

When Printed, Assemble base assembly before adding any extras to the pegs. To make the drawers more air-tight simply apply a thin layer of silicone from the hardware store. The close fitting drawers will keep enough pressure to block out air

author: htbui

description.text: The Mini Racer is fast, compact and fuel-effecient. An aerodynamic design and minimalist take on suspension allow for maximum speed across hardwood or linoleum flooring. Its modern styling distinguish this 3D Printed car from other toys that may have rolled under the couch. JD Power and Associates have never heard of the Mini Racer. But if they ever do, they'll likely print one for themselves and place it next to their trophy. I made this toy for my son and his Little People® City Skyway. We wanted more cars. Instead of buying them separately, we designed and printed our own. Design your own with the Mini Racer OpenSCAD library.

To assemble the racer, print one of the three bodies, four wheels, four hubcaps and two axles. Snap the hubcaps into the wheels. Thread the axles through the holes in the body and mount the wheels. I like to print the body and hubcaps in one color and the axles and wheels in black. The cars pictured were printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2 at 0.2mm resolution. I used Simplify3D to arrange the components and manually added supports to the wheel wells. All parts used 10% infill except the axles which used 100%. If you want to customize a Mini Racer, clone the Mini Racer repo,
download and run OpenSCAD, open racer.scad and follow the instructions.

Somewhere along the line of multiple iterations of printed upgrades I ended up with a permanent angle between the Y and Z axis. To correct for this, I came up with the adjustable YZ version of my 300mm No Sag for the Printrbot Simple versions BEFORE the 1405. For the 1405 version please see:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:723004 I have been running with this upgrade since Feb. 2015 and am very happy. What I have done here is split the YZ plate from the original 300mm No Sag, and bolted it back together with slotted holes. You should be able to get about 5 degrees of adjustment up and down. One word of warning, the adjustment bolt bracket is not very strong. I would not suggest trying to crank up the angle with any tension on the mounting bolts. If you were using the bearing blocks before, they are not possible with an adjustable angle. I have included routes for zip ties.

description.text: This design has been moved to https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-simple-metal-feet-abd41a8d-9709-4681-8286-3241910c0753 I wanted a set of feet for my 3D printer that were very stable. I've created an additional front foot with a slot for an SD card.

This is a touch probe for a CNC machine. The probe consists of a set of 3D printed parts and some hardware available from McMaster Carr. The 3D printed parts do not include threads for the fasteners so they will need to be tapped prior to assembly. The stepped boss on the top of the probe is designed to fit into either a 1/4 or 1/2 inch collet for easy mounting on the CNC machine. If you need some software to put your new probe to good use check out G-Code Ripper. It will map an existing g-code file to a probed surface. http://www.scorchworks.com/Gcoderipper/gcoderipper.html A lot of the designing of this part was performed on my Android phone using ScorchCAD (While traveling or waiting for my kids to be done with practice for various activities). http://www.scorchworks.com/ScorchCAD/scorchcad.html

Instructions
After I assembled the probe I found that adding a very small amount of lithium grease to the interface between the shoulder screws and round head screws helped the probe return to the closed position after each probe point
For the probe tip I ground down a short length of 1/4 inch threaded rod to a point. The tip is threaded into the shaft part so I can swap it out for another tip depending on what I want to probe.

Mechanical Parts: (with McMaster-Carr Part Numbers)
91259A535 3 Each Alloy Steel Shoulder Screw, 1/4" Diameter X 3/8" Long Shoulder, 10-24 Thread 1692K58 1 Pack Type 302 Ss Conical Compression Spring, .625"l,.720" Large Od,.375" Small Od,.040" Wire 90279A148 1 Pack Znc Pltd Stl Round Head Phillip Machine Screw, 6-32 Thread, 1/2" Length 90760A007 1 Pack Zinc Plated Steel Narrow Hex Nut, 6-32 Thread Size, 1/4" Wide, 3/32" High 98032A436 1 Pack Mil Spec. Cadmium-plated Steel Flat Washer, Number 6 Screw Size, Ms-27183-43, 0.156" Id

Electrical Components:
Resistors, (3x) 12 kOhm Transistor, BC547B Earphone Jack (3.5 mm), Radio Shack, 274-0249
(The inverting circuit is not needed if you have your probe set up to trigger when the probe is an open circuit.)

Tools Needed:
General Purpose Tap, Thread Size 6-32 (McMaster 2522A717)
General Purpose Tap, Thread Size 1/4"-20 (McMaster 2521A621)

title: XYZPrinting Da Vinci 1.0/2.0 Duo/AiO Side Caps/Covers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I know a fair amount of people have been waiting for these for a while so here they are... side covers for you Da Vinci printer! They will keep little plastic bit from going into the gap on the left and right side of the printer. The covers are held by the ribs of the side panel. These are meant to work with the corner caps I previously made: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:699003 These look like they will work for the AiO but the right panels will need to be cut to fit. All that's needed now are some covers in between the side panels and the metal frame. The back also has a gap but a board of some sort seems more appropriate for that. Anyhow, enjoys :)

The covers consist of 8 parts: 1x left_top.stl
1x left_bottom.stl
1x right_top.stl
1x right_bottom.stl
2x end_cap_2.stl
2x end_cap_1.stl I suggest attaching the end caps to the covers using acetone to weld them together. You can also weld the side cover half together if you feel the need but that will make them harder to remove if you have to. If you have a Da Vinci 2.0 Duo like I do I highly suggest that you print only two side covers at a time to prevent one of the print head from crashing into the metal retainers for the hot plate. It happened to me :( For the AiO the right side covers will need to be cut to fit around the scanner.

description.text: I designed this glider in 3DFoil and printed it using the .stl export feature. The calculation show that the glider will trim out at 6 degrees (C.G. at wing leading edge) and glide for about 20 - 30 ft. (not tested). The wing span is 4 inches. The stl is saved in meters (not inches). Launch with rubber band. Visit http://www.hanleyinnovations.com for simulation software..

I used the 3DFoil software to create this glider. The following video shows the process: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lqRrQ5FSCXA.
If you are making this glider, use a really light material such as foam. Plastic might not work. Be sure to adjust the center of gravity (by adding small weights) so that it balances at the wing leading edge.

author: plusalphaDesigns

description.text:
This is part of my Baby-Huey large format 3D printer project.
http://nerdipedia.com/tiki-index.php?page=huey A fixing system similar to a rawlplug for plugging into the end of a square tube. It is a filleted square plug with a tapered hexagonal hole to hold a nut. The design file is parametric so nutsize, tubesize and taper can all be changed with a simple parameter edit.
It is my first freeCAD project so maybe not the most elegant design but it is a start.
This isn't going to be super strong but should work OK for something like a 3D printer frame.

expansion-plug-a.stl is sized for a 25mm square tube with 3mm wall thickness. The nut is 13.5mm face to face and the taper is 5 degrees. I intend to resize for metric but didn't have any suitable nut and bolts on hand. I think ABS would work best but my test print was in PLA and it seemed to work perfectly. I had to give it a little rub with a file to get it to go in. I The round hole was a but tight too and I drill it out.
The expansion seemed to work but I haven't used it for anything serious.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:55821 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=55821

Just got a bonsai tree and decided it needed a Chinese pavilion to go with it!  
It comes in three parts, that fit together and hold fine, but should really be glued together as it's simple peg and hole mating.  
The picture in the plant is after using the acetone fume smoothing technique. Unfortunately my printer couldn't quite get the small ridges on part of the roof, not sure why but it still looks good after smoothing.   
Feel free to leave any comments or questions!  
-Mike

Update: This thing won 3rd place in the Thingiverse / GE Firstbuild
'Countertop Challenge' https://firstbuild.com/blog/post/countertop-challenge-winners/299/

This is my entry in GE Firstbuild's 'Countertop Challenge' The ‘micro-BLOCK’ is a tribute to the micro-KITCHEN and offers an organized, compact, and aesthetic way to keep your most important cooking and baking instruments easily accessible right on the countertop. Its great for kitchens that may not have a lot of drawer space and awesome for connected kitchens of the future. The micro-BLOCK’s best forward-thinking feature is an embedded touchscreen device which is meant to serve as your connected kitchen’s control panel and an access point for Green-Bean enhanced appliances. You could also use the display to stream how-to cooking video’s, or any other functionality a killer kitchen app might provide. The micro-BLOCK also has a convenient ledge to hold your tablet up off the messy countertop at the perfect recipe-reading angle.
The micro-BLOCK provides storage for all these common cooking and baking instruments. Not everyone's tools are the same but the micro-BLOCK is designed with enough flexibility to accommodate most common sizes and form factors . 8” Carving Knife
Utility Knife
Set of 4 Steak Knives
Measuring Cups (1, 3/4, 1/3, 1/2, 1/4)
Measuring Spoons (1Tbl, 1Tsp, 1/2Tbl, 1/2 Tsp, 1/4 Tbl)
Serving Spoon
Slotted Spoon
Slotted Spatula
Digital Cooking Timer
Pairing Knife
Meat Thermometer
Bottle Opener / Cork Screw
Vegetable Peeler
Can Punch
2 Packs of Matches

Upper Block
7% Fill, 2 Shells, Medium Layer Height Lower Base
7% Fill, 3 Shells, Medium Layer Height Everything Else:
20% Fill, 2 Shells Medium Layer Height The clearance fits of pins and feet should be tight, tap with a hammer if needed, no glue required but wouldn't hurt either.

comments.text: Its a beautiful print. I do a lot of cooking and my one design criticism would be the usability. In a connected kitchen I would want to be able see the screen / make adjustments to it, look up info and grab my knives from the same side of the counter. With your design, it would require the constant turning back and forth of the knife block. If you have it set up on a counter to grab knives then the drawer is potentially backed up against the back-splash / back wall. If you have it turned to see the screen then the knives are not accessible and require you to pull them out in a dangerous way. With messy cooking hands, it's not always going to be practical to turn the knife block around to get what you need.

The workshop was hosted by the FabLab Aachen2 of the Media Computing Group and supervised by many helpers, including Josef Prusa. Since we included a PCB Heatbead Mk1 3, we had to modify the design for the "print plates"... the design was also used at the workshop in Maastricht (for 10 more RepRap Prusa Mendel printers). The parts replace the following (listed in the Prusa Mendel BOM[4]):
225mmÃ—225mm print top plate
140mmÃ—225mm print bottom plate [4]: http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Prusa -> Non-Printed Parts ("vitamins")

title: A/C Compressor Housing for geared motor.  22RE Engine

description.text: This is a modified compressor housing to fit a larger 12v 120rpm motor for the 22RE to overcome some of the issues that come from using the smaller 3v motor. There is not room for batteries so you will have to figure out that part. My plan was to use the lithium battery listed below. Also, the shaft is 4mm so you will need to carefully bore out the old pulley. Eventually, I plan to build a circuit to PWM the motor off the 12v and link that to the throttle body using a pot so you can rev the motor like a real one. http://www.ebay.com/itm/Li-po-Rechargeable-Battery-Pack-for-CCTV-Camera-12V-1800mAh-Quick-Delivery-OF-/261679507457?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item3ced506801 Link to the motor I used on ebay http://www.amazon.com/HOSSEN%C2%AE-120RPM-Powerful-Torque-Replacement/dp/B00B1KZ8UU/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1426217591&sr=8-1&keywords=12v+120rpm+motor

description.text: I have these pencils from my way back and they all have the flat eraser. Meaning I used what could be used and since I have now taken them out of of an old box I had, I needed to use a pencil and noticed that the eraser was gone. Or what could be used. So I just made these adapters to go under what's left of the eraser to lift it up and give me a bit more of the eraser. Not a big thing but how annoying is this, you go and pick up the pencil and you realized there is no more eraser that you an use. I got a few other erasers but I thought I use these small parts to learn FreeCad. It took me a while, but I got them made. Make sure to get the right one since they are different sizes. I'm attaching a picture of the pencil so you know what it fits.

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/elf-open-share-3d-vr-nano-drone Main Features:
  • Open source. Which is to say, ELF is a development platform for makers, not just a toy. Using the most common seen open source hardware Arduino programming environment, ELF can be reviewed into what you want by modifying the codes and hardware.
  • 3D printed shell. 3D print hobbyists can download the software from Thingiverse and print their own drone. Choose printing filaments of whatever color to print their personalized drones. They can also design theirs.
  • Compact, ultra-portable. Safer, easy to fly indoors.
  • Smartphone app control. Support for iOS and Android (Bluetooth 4.0 and later version). Using Bluetooth low energy (BLE) on smartphones and wifi as powerful computing capability. ELF allows real-time photo & video share anywhere.
  • 720P high definition wifi cam. 720P visual quality record and VGA-quality real-time transmission.
  • Ultrasonic constant level flight. (doing)

    We make and share. We're ElecFreaks.

1kg MakerBot filament spool holder for 5th Generation MakerBots by admg consultancy This will work on the 5th Generation Replicator, the Z18 and the Mini. It allows use of MakerBot 1kg filament spools, while retaining the captured filament guide tube which is important for reliable printing. The guide tube can be up to 6mm outside diameter (OD). This is a from-scratch design in OpenSCAD that I made to give greater flexibility to use 1kg MakerBot PLA spools on the 5th Generation MakerBots. Not intended for use with generic PLA, flexible filament, ABS, strimmer wire... Credits:
1) It makes use of v1.4 of Dan Kirshner's excellent OpenSCAD thread library - http://dkprojects.net/openscad-threads/threads.scad
2) Also br3ttb's MakerBot M logo in OpenSCAD form: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11105
Enjoy - and please post any feedback you may have. UPDATED FILES 22 March 2015:
The tolerances on the threads have been improved to allow for a snug fit with minimal cleanup on a standard print. UPDATE 26 March 2015:
Included a 6mm OD tube to Replicator 5G/Mini extruder adapter, to allow use of 6mmOD, 4mm ID PTFE tube. This is pretty basic, I have begun a design that grips more solidly to the extruder, but this does the job in the meantime. UPDATE 01 May 2015:
Reworked the spool holder to reduce the radius slightly to match tolerances on some spools, and add the option to tightly grip filament guide tubes with outside diameter 4mm.
Also updated the smart extruder - 6mm guide tube adapter to improve fit. This is not suitable for use with Z18 smart extruders with swivel top clip - instead use the Z18's existing guide tube.

1) Print all 3 .makerbot files. They are sliced at 0.2mm (200micron) layer height. They look great in True Black or True Red. The retainer is optimised to print logo face down so that you can use a contrasting colour for the logo - if you want to match your machine, start in MakerBot True Red and pause after 0.5mm and reload with True Black filament. Some 1kg reels are wound clockwise and some anti-clockwise - the spacer is to allow you to use either. 2) Add filament guide tube
This is optimised for 6mm OD (Outside diameter), 4mm ID (Inside diameter) PTFE tube. Or you can use the existing filament guide tube.

description.text:
Ever pull your earbuds out of your pocket, see the tangled mess, and wonder how much more abuse they will put up with?  Yeah!  Me too!  I happen to like the set of earbuds in the photo so much that I've cut back the wires and soldered them several times already.  
Then I started using my 3D design brain and said, "Brain! Make me something to save my earbuds!"  So it did!  It took a couple of revisions, but the result is this cute little thing that's smaller than the average thumb drive so it doesn't require gobs of pocket real estate.  Good job 3D design brain!

This thing is easy, easy to make.
  • Download.
  • Print with 0.25mm resolution or finer
  • Add small safety pin through the holes provided, and then
    • YOUR DONE! The world is now safe from the earbud destructors that lie in wait inside of every dark pocket of society. No more evil super knots in your pocket. Our job is done here.

title: 12V LED fitting for 25mm Aluminium Box Tube - for 30mm LED arrays.

description.text:
I use 25mm aluminium box tube for the horizontal bars on my roof racks.
I designed these to simply slot onto them, and plug into a cigarette lighter socket. as I have one of these on a secondary battery as well. Simple assembly - you will need:
1X 3X20mm nut and bolt per assembly
1X LED array
Some appropriate wire (grommet hole is 4mm) The LED units can be purchased as 12v halogen replacements from Jarcar dealers in Australia - and are polarity corrected, or you can find various suppliers of the 30mm version on aliexpress.com for much cheaper (I found some for 80c each - but they we much dimmer) Any troubles - leave a comment and I'll do what I can.
I have left the tolerances fairly loose, as people complained about tight tolerances in my Swiss army SD card holder design.

voici une chatière assez pratique, elle évite de faire un gros trou dans la porte, vous aurez seulement 4 petit trous de vis. Je l'utilise pour laisser passer les chats dans la chambre et pas les chiens.
Attention lors de la pose, pensez à laisser au moins 15mm entre le bloc fixé sur la porte et le bord de la porte!!!! sinon vous ne pourrez plus fermer la porte (à cause du chambranle).
pour ouvrir il suffit de mettre le doigt sous la goupille coté porte, et de la sortir, puis vous pouvez replier le bras, et fermer la porte normalement. ps: je vous conseil de fixer l'ensemble un peu au dessus de la
poignée, évidemment l'effort sur l'ensemble sera plus important si

I did some math and found that there are 6 driver bits I use most commonly, so I made room for 6, which is a nice number actually. I suggest you print the base, and V2 cap.
the original cap was a bit of a failed design attempt but I left it in for those who like a bigger, smooth grip. It probably has combinations I haven't worked out yet, and source is included if you think you can do it better - or just want to build on the idea.

I created a very basic groovemount plate in two pieces that can be used together to secure a hot end such as the Hexagon hot end.

Print and slide the pieces over the hotend.

Lid to use wide mouth container to trap bedbugs or other insects.

This lid fits jars with a 4.25 inch diameter mouth; this jar came from some mixed nuts that I bought at a local store.

Carbon dioxide is needed to trap the bugs, and there are many online recipes using dry yeast, sugar, and water.

.

Here is my design of an enclosure for a squeezebox based on a Raspberry Pi2, Hifiberry DAC+ and Watterott 5" HDMI Touchscreen-Display. Video:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tN6ngN8lytw

Part P03_Case should be printed with support but with "Don´t support bridges" aktivated (in Slic3r). So the breakout holes for USB and Network will not be closed by support pillars.
Look at the pictures and the freecad file to see how to assemble. They are self explainary. Bill of materials you need:
Raspberry Pi2 (or B+ should work either) 5"-Touchscreen (http://www.watterott.com/de/5-800x480-HDMI-Display-mit-resistivem-Touchscreen) Hifiberry DAC+ (http://www.watterott.com/de/HiFiBerry-BPlus-DAC-RCA-version or https://www.hifiberry.com/product/hifiberry-dacplus-rca-version/ IR receiver 38 kHz 950 nm (Vishay TSOP4838) (e.g. http://www.conrad.de/ce/de/product/171115/IR-Empfaenger-Sonderform-axial-bedrahtet-38-kHz-950-nm-Vishay-TSOP4838?queryFromSuggest=true) 2 Micro USB plug Type B
1 USB plug A 90°
2 HDMI plug 1.3
4 bolts M3 x 10 mm
2 Cynch panel jacks
1 hollow plug socket for central mounting (power supply)
Some self-tapping screws to assemble everything together. For the USB and HDMI connection you need to assemble your own cables because commercial available ones are not enough flexible to fit in the case. I builded up both cables from single wires.
HDMI output of the Pi2 goes to HDMI-In of the watterott output adapter.
USB out of the Pi2 goes to data In of the watterott Display adapter.
Because the solded Cynch plugs of the hifiberry are to big to fit in the case, you have to cut them of and rewire the signals of each hifi output to the Cynch panel jacks at the rear panel. The IR reciever module fits in the center hole of the front panel. It is connected to +3,3V, GND and GPIO14 on the GPIO multi-pin connector by single wires. Last but not least build up a short cable with micro USB plug to the power panel jack at the rear panel. Software:
I use raspbian 3.18 from the Pi webside. Install hifiberry drivers as described in the hifiberry forum (https://www.hifiberry.com/guides/configuring-linux-3-18-x/), flash the firmware to the HDMI display adapter and adjust the required settings in the adapter firmware (orientation of the display, touchscreen calibration, screen saver deactivation, etc.). This is described at githup (https://github.com/watterott/HDMI-Display).
Modify /boot/config.txt with the right display settings (https://github.com/watterott/HDMI-Display/blob/master/docu/config.txt).
Install softsqueeze in /home/pi/softsqueeze from http://sourceforge.net/projects/softsqueeze/. You can download the Windowsversion and copy the complete folder to your pi home directory. What you need in the end is only the SoftSqueeze.jar file.
Modify /etc/xdg/lxsession/LXDE-pi/autostart to:
/# @lxpanel --profile LXDE-pi
/# @pcmanfm --desktop --profile LXDE-pi
@xscreensaver -no-splash
@java -jar /home/pi/Softsqueeze/SoftSqueeze.jar After rebooting your pi will come up with X without Windowmanager and Softsqueeze in the middle of your display. Install LIRC and customize it to your favorite IR remote (/etc/lirc/hardware.conf and /etc/lirc/lircrc). Dont forget to modify /boot/config.txt by adding:
dtoverlay=lirc-rpi,gpio_in_pin=14 Have fun!

description.text: this enables wades idler to be adjusted by hand. it should work on m4 and m5 nuts OK. i mistakenly stated it was for m3. my bad. i may follow up with a parametric design.

print out 4 nobs from stl file, press 4m or 5m nut into inset, and hold solder gun to nut to push in in and hold it in place. reverse your normal wades setup placing bolt top in back of wades, and place nuts into nob holder and then place idler, and springs, then thread the nuts on by hand. tighten till snug.

comments.text: This may work where you live but here in the US virtually none of these materials are readily available.  I had to substitute 3/4" galvanized thin wall steel conduit with 1/2" Pex tubing for the top piece and then redraw the parts to suit.  I would need to source 5/8" Pex (3/4" OD)which is almost non existent here in the US and only available as a bulk purchase from Amazon and BTW, since it hasn't been tested I have no assurance that it would work due to flexibility concerns.  The Flags are well made but for the US Customers there will be some fabrication to be done to make these flags work.  What really needs to happen is that the sleeve area on the flags need to be stitched so that you can use standard Schedule 40 PVC which is .840" in diameter.
